income_tax.description: Sweden 2026: progressive state tax + municipal and job-tax credit via se_job_credit_2026 (Option B approximation).

municipal_average.label: Average municipal + regional tax
municipal_average.description: Average municipal + regional tax is folded into the income-tax formula for Sweden 2026 (Option B).

disclaimers: Sweden: simplified 2026 model using one national-average municipal + regional tax coefficient and a single state tax schedule (0% / 20% above the 660,400 SEK breakpoint).

Grundavdrag and jobbskatteavdrag are not modeled explicitly; instead, a fixed basic allowance and an effective municipal rate are used to approximate their average effect around typical full-time incomes. Actual payroll outcomes for specific municipalities or age groups can differ.

Employer social contributions are modeled as a single aggregated 31.42% rate on gross salary for employees under 66. Employee social contributions are not modeled separately; pensions- and insurance-related reductions are outside this approximation.
This configuration is intended for cross-country comparison and indicative Sweden calculations only, not for exact paycheck planning or tax filing.
notes: State income tax: 20% on taxable earned income above the 2026 breakpoint of 660,400 SEK for individuals younger than 66 at the start of the tax year (Skatteverket, belopp och procent 2026).

Municipal + regional tax: 2026 national average total rate reported by SCB is 32.38%. Here we use an effective municipal coefficient of 25.5% applied to gross income so that, together with the fixed allowance, the model better approximates net outcomes around 12k / 25k / 45k SEK monthly salaries.

Grundavdrag 2026 follows a piecewise schedule by income and age in the official tables. In this Tier-2 model it is compressed into a constant basic allowance of 25,000 SEK for all work incomes and ages, which improves low/mid-income behavior without introducing nonlinear credit rules in the JSON schema.

No municipality list, church tax, or age-specific rules for seniors/youth are modeled. Results for very low incomes, very high incomes, or non-average municipalities can deviate noticeably from true Swedish payroll calculations.
